Emperor Wu
compared to his predecessors in this

impotent relatives from challenging
Authority but also isolated Emperor's
from their natural allies this meant
that if the ruler was a child or was

fill for Wei this system had caused the
vacuum which had allowed the Sima clan

to extensively involve his family in
running the Empire twenty-seven of his

of prince and appointed to rule over

vassals and now they had actual

fiefs
the right to have a guard and permission

of law yang if they wanted the princes
being in the capital and having

Wu believed this policy of empowering

malloon declared himself the Emperor
leading to an intermittent civil war

Jin princes were busy ripping their own

according to the Chinese sources they
were apparently treated like slaves by
the Jin dynasty and because of this

Chinese strength due to Civil War the
various nomadic peoples began to revolt

own states essentially splitting the
Jin's northern territory away by 311 in
the same year the people known as the Wu
who managed to sack the Jin capital of
lor yang killed the Jin Crown Prince a
score of valuable officials and around
30,000 civilians this moment is seen as
the final nail in
a coffin of the greater Western Jin
dynasty and the beginning of the eastern
Jin in a wider sense the chaos in
northern China led to mass migrations of
Han Chinese south of the Wye River and
an era of fragmentation which lasted for
almost another century
